titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.48 Richmond, Va. Wednesday, February 25, 1863 price one cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: A Legal opinion of the Conscript act — highly important decision.
div3.p:
A habeas corpus case, involving more questions of general interest than any which has yet been brought before the country, was decided by Judge Meredith yesterday, after elaborate and protracted argument.
It involves the right of the Government to the military services of a large number of able-bodied residents of the Confederacy, between the ages of eighteen and forty, who have heretofore been considered as exempt from military duty.
The facts are briefly as follows:

q.p:
William and Charles P. Harman at the commencement of the existing war were living in the District of Columbia with their father, who had in the year 1855 removed from Alexandria to Washington, in consequence of having received an appointment of clerk in one of the departments of Government.
His sons were born in Virginia, and at the commencement of the war one was of age and the other a minor.
In April or May, 1861, both of them enlisted in a volunteer company, and entered the military service of the Confederate States.
They served for twelve months and ninety days, and then claimed their discharge upon the ground of being of the Confederate States.
The validity of their claim was conceded by Col. Taliaferro, the enrolling officer for the Cherlottesville district, and they were furnished with exemption papers.
They were, however, subsequently arrested by order of the Colonel of the regiment in which they had served, and held to military service under the conscript act of April 16, 1862.

div3.p:
The petitioners appealed for and obtained writs of habeas corpus for the purpose of ascertaining whether they were liable to military duty as "residents" of the Confederacy.
In the hearing of the case, before Judge Meredith, Hon. Shelton F. Leake appeared for the petitioners, and made use of the various points bearing upon the case, to procure their discharge.
P. H. Aylett, Erq., Confederate States District Attorney, appeared for the War Department, and resisted the application for the discharge of the petitioners.
The argument on both sides was able and elaborate.

Judge Moredith delivered a long and able opinion, in which he sustained with much force and learning the points made by the counsel for the Government.
He decided that the removal of the petitioners' father to Washington to accept a clerkship in the Post-Office Department had not changed the domicil either of the father or of his family, as the office was one revocable at the will of the appointing power, and that the residence of the petitioners there was from "necessity," arising from the authority of the father.
He also decided that, admitting the father of the petitioners to have acquired a domicil in Washington, the petitioners, as native-born Virginians, had, at the commencement of the war, an undoubted right to resume their native citizenship, and that by returning to the domicil of their origin, and by taking up arms to fight our battles, they had furnished the highest and most conclusive evidence of their voluntary resumption of their rights as citizens of Virginia — Against such acts as these the Judge said that more declarations of the animus of the petitioners should not be permitted to weigh.

Judge Mergdith commented on and sustained the point (made by Mr. Aylett) that the domicil of the soldier was that of the country in whose service he was enlisted.
Nothing, he said, could be clearer than that by entering the military service you acquire a domicil.
He cited and commented upon a large number of interesting decisions in England, France, Germany, and America, to show that no principle of law was more clearly established than the one contended for by the counsel for the Government, and expressed the opinion that every citizen of Maryland and every foreigner who had once enlisted in our armies, it mattered not for how brief a period, was a fit subject for conscription, if between the ages of eighteen and forty, and he expressed the hope that the War Department would at once all persons thus liable.

The language of this Conscript act, the learned Judge said, was exceedingly broad.
It evidently contemplated the conscription of all "residents" in the Confederate States between the specified years.
Whether they were residents in pursuit of pleasure, money, or what not, they were clearly liable, under the broad language of the act, and should be conscribed.
The Judge also decided that the War Department could disregard all exemptions which had been given by enrolling officers where they had been improperly given.
The petitioners, he decided, were not held at this time in custody of the proper official, and were therefore entitled to their discharge; but it was strictly legitimate and proper for the proper enrolling officer for the Albmarie district to enroll them as conscripts, and make the proper disposal of them under the provisions of the Conscript act of 16th April, 1862.
It is understood that no appeal will be taken from this important decision, and the action of the War Department and of the numerous enrolling officers will doubtless conform to it.

div4.head:
Tuesday, February 24, 1863.
Specie and Bank notes.
div4.p:
--Quotations remain as last reported, viz: Gold $2 30 prem; Silver $2 10--selling rates.
For Bank Notes of the several States brokers continue to pay 34@36 per cent, and salt at 38@40.
Exchange on London nominal at $2 25@2 30.

div4.head: Bonds and stocks.
div4.p:
--The Stock market is quiet, and prices generally remain unchanged.
We again quote Confederate bonds, (100 miles) at 100½ and interest, payable in new currency.
Under a recent act of Congress all bonds issued after the hundred million loan is filled, (which cannot he far off,) will be redeemable at the pleasure of the Government, at the expiration of five years from the date thereof.
Those now issue are redeemable at "long dates" The currency question is new pending in Congress, and until the subject is disposed of financial operations will not be active.--We again quote Virginia sixes at 103; North Carolina sixes, 12½ do. eights 110 and interest.

div4.head: Produce.
div4.p:
--Wheat continues at $3 40@3 50 for prime red and white, with but little doing, except on Government account.
Corn $4 25 and source Flour firmer and in better demand; Superfine $20@21, Extra $22@23, Family $23 @25. Corn Meal $4 25@4 50 such.
The Tobacco market is less active, but sales continue to be made at high rates.
Bacon, hoground, $1 05@1 10, Apples in less demand sales at $35@40 bbl. Butter in great demand at $1 50 @2 per lb, as to quality.
Lard $1 10@1 15.
Tallow 75 cts. Country Soap 80 cts @81 lb. Clover Seed lower; sales at $25 @27 such, Timothy $7@8.
Dried Apples $7 50@8; Dried Peaches $1 2@1 5 bush.
Irish Potatoes $5@6 bush.
Onions $40@50 bbl. Eggs 90 cts @81 dozen, (wholesale.) Dressed Fowis 87½ cts @81 lb. Beans $7 50@8 bush.
Peas $7@8 bush.
Beeswax 75 cts@81 lb. Hay 84 50@ 5 ewt.

div4.head: Auction Sale.
div4.p: --At Kent, Paine & Co's auction sale to- day, the following prices were obtained for groceries, &c.

Brown Sugar 52@83 cts; White Clarified $1 07; Crushed $1 57, Molesses $8 per gallon; Coffee $3 50 per lb; Green Tea $9 25@2 25; Salt 20@22 cents; Soap 35 cts@31; Shot 65@70 cts; Madeira Wine $7 25@8 25 per bottle; do, in cook, $21 25 per gallon; Whiskey $15 23@$28 per gallon; Old Drowry Apple Brandy $30 50 per gallon; Champagne $9@9 25 per bottle.

div3.head: Death from swallowing false teeth.
div3.p:
--On Saturday afternoon an inquiry was held at the Prince Regent Tavern, Globe Road Mile-End, by Mr. Walthew, respecting the death of Mary Harsington, aged fifty-six, which occurred from swallowing a plate of false teeth.
James Stephens said that last Tuesday deceased, while walking across the room, put both hands to her breast, and uttered a piercing scream.
He caught her and placed her on the sofa.
He thought she was in a fit, and ran for help.
She died almost immediately in great agony.
Dr. J. Relly said that he was called in and found deceased had just died.
He took from the trachea a false tooth and a portion of the metal plate.--There was the corresponding portion on the metal plate fixed to the palate.
The metal was of the commonest material, and was so soft that the nail could be easily put through it. It was highly dangerous to manufacture plates of such porous, weak metal.
There was a lamp of ginger in the mouth, and no double in bling if the plate broke, and deceased swallowed suffocation. "The jury returned a verdict" That deceased lost her life through misfortune."-- English paper.

div3.head: Great snow Storm.
div3.p:
--On Wednesday night, 4th instant, this section was visited by one of the severest snow storms ever experienced since the first settlement of the country.
For several hours in the night the wind blew a perfect hurricane, prostrating fences, injuring some houses, and blowing down insurance quantities of large timber.
The snow drifted very much, but was supposed to have averaged four inches deep.--Jacksonville (Ala.) Republican.
--I have received to-day Northern papers of the 20th and 21st instants, and send the following summary of the news they contain:

div4.head: Important resolutions of the Connecticut Democracy — Comments of the New York times thereon.
div4.p: The New York Times, of the 20th, under the head of "The New Hartford Convention," has the following:

q.p:
We hope no one will fall to read the series of resolutions adopted by the Connecticut Democratic Convention, which, on Wednesday, nominated Mr. T. H. Paymour for Governor of that State.
The issue with the Administration is clearly put. The policy of a cessation of hostilities with the rebels is boldly proclaimed . The doctrine of State sovereignly and independence is asserted to the first resolution, while the "hereby of " is oddly enough repudiated in the third.
The conscription bill is declared to be subversive of the sovereignty of the States; the State authorities are called upon to "sternly resist" its operation.
The "banking system" adopted by the Senate is pronounced unconstitutional and dangerous to the principles on which our Government is founded.
The emancipation is recalled.
A categorical statement of the recent "usurpations" of the National Administration is made, and it is declared that if sanctioned they will destroy the Union and "establish upon the common ruins of the liberties of the people and the sovereignties of the States a consolidated military despotism" A great many other things are protested against and denounced; and about the only thing in our recent history that is not denounced in the rebellion of the Southern traitors and the atrocious usurpations of the Richmond despotism.

div4.p:
The political issue is certainly clear enough in the State of Connecticut.
It is rebellion and loyalty.--It far overrides any issue over made in the Northern States.
The platform is up to the South Carolina standard in every particular.
The nominee for Governor stands squarely upon it. Jeff Davis has triumphed in the State Convention it remains to be seen whether he will triumph in the State.--We suppose the Connecticut soldiers in the field will have a vote on the subject.

The following are the resolutions referred to above, unanimously adopted by the Democratic Convention at Hartford, on the 18th, as the platform of the party, and vociferously cheered during their reading.

Hon. Thos. H. Seymour was nominated for Governor, and promptly accepted.
Hon. Isaac Toncey promised to stump the State for him.

The preamble sets forth that it is the privilege and duty of a free people fearlessly to assert their rights, and freely to canvass the acts of their appointed servants; that the present Administration has assessed powers utterly at variance with the letter and spirit of the Constitution, and it becomes us firmly and temperately to condemn the errors of our public officers: Therefore.

Resolved I, That the United States are a confederacy of States co-equal in sovereignty and political power; independent in their separate organizations, and reserving to each all powers not granted by the Constitution to the Central Government.

The second resolution deliberately avows that the liberties of the people are menaced by Congressional and Federal usurpations, and can only be preserved by the energetic action of State authority, and we are determined to maintain and defend the honor of our State and the rights of our people.

The third resolution denounces the heresy of secession as unwarranted by the Constitution, but confidently asserts the time has now arrived when all true lovers of the Constitution are ready to abandon "the monstrous fallacy" that the Union can be restored by the armed hand; and are anxious to inaugurate such measures as will stop the ravages of war, avert universal bankruptcy, and unite all the States upon terms of equality as members of one confederacy.

The 4th resolution pledges them to unite with conservatives in the Middle and Western States to stop the war; reconstruct the Union on such terms as shall thoroughly define the rights of the States, and reproduce friendly feelings, &c.

V. That the militia of Connecticut are the natural guardians of the liberties of her people, subject to the control of her chief Executive officer, acting under and by authority of the laws of the State; and any and all acts of the United States Congress violative of State sovereignty in relation thereto should receive the execration of a people justly jealous of their liberties--"who know their rights, and, knowing, dare maintain."

VI.
That the Militia bill in the United States Senate is subversive of the sovereignty and rights of the States, unconstitutional and dangerous and the authorities of each State should sternly resist its operation.

VII., says the "banking system" recently passed, based on an unconstitutional and irredeemable paper currency, will be destructive of existing moneyed institutions, and is covertly designed to establish a "money power" unknown to the Constitution and dangerous to its principles.

VIII That the President by his emancipation proclamation has struck a serious blow at the rights of the States; erected an almost impassable barrier between the North and South in attacking the people of fifteen States, through an institution which is blended with their social fabric, and over which the individual States possess exclusive control and power; and regardless of the great lessons of the past, the national Executive, in pandering to the furane fanaticism of the Abolition faction, has ventured upon a system of public policy which, if successfully inaugurated would of grace our country in the eyes of the civilized world, and carry last, murder, and rapine it to every household of the slaveholding States.

IX.
That the act of the Federal Administration in suspending the writ of habeas corpus, the abridgement of freedom of speech and of the press in suppressing newspapers by force, and establishing censorship incompatible with freedom of thought and expression; in establishing espionage by secret police; in declaring martial law; in attempting to strike out of existence the entire value of property in slaves; in attempted enforcement of compensated emancipation; In attempting taxation of the white man to purchase the freedom of the negro, and place his labor in competition with the white man thus taxed; in the dismemberment of the State of Virginia, erecting within her boundaries a new State, without the consent of her Legislature — are each and all arbitrary and unconstitutional subverting the Constitutions, State and Federal, invading the reserved rights of the people and the sovereignty of the States, and if sanctioned, destructive of the Union, and establishing a consolidated military despotism.

And we hereby solemnly declare that no American citizen can without crime sanction such usurpations.
Believing silence will be criminal, we do hereby enter our most solemn protest against these ruthless violations of the Constitution.
X. Pledges their utmost influence to prevent the payment of a dollar for compensated emancipation.

XI.
Demands scrutiny and punishment and exposure of self constituted plunderers of the public Treasury.

XII.
Sympathizes with the soldiers, and demands punishment for these who have deprived them of proper food, raiment, and care.

XIII.
Gemmule exposure of the expenditure of four millions appropriated by Connecticut during the past two years, and protests against the two thousand dollars given the Governor for secret service money.
The election will take place the 4th Monday in April.

div4.head: The rebellion.
div4.p:
It was reported in Washington that the attack on Charleston and Savannah was to take place on the 20th.
The guns at Charleston number $90, (an ominous number,) and some of them are of immense calibre.

Gen. Gorman is clearing out the Yazoo Pass to make it navigable to the black water, and thus reach the rear of Vicksburg.
Stumps. trees, &c., choke up the passage.
His picket force, half a mile ahead, have had skirmishes, and some killed on both sides.
The rebels have cannon where the pass cutters the Blackwater.
On the 11th the clearing had advanced within two miles of that point.
The Queen of the West smashed the wheels and guards and stove a large hole in the side of the Vicksburg, when she "butted" her on her passage down.

The Alabama, on the 25th and 27th, captured and burnt the bark Golden Rule and the brigs Chattelaine, of Boston.
The Hanover, of Boston, was captured and burnt by a privateer, the Retribution, near Hayti.
As soon as Congress grants letters of marque three swill steamers will be sent after the Ambuma and Florida.

Rosecrans, on the 12th, routed 590 of Murgan't cavalry, killed 20, and took 6 prisoners 50 horses, and destroyed 200 stand of arms, and had only three men wounded.
Morgan is near Cainsville.
The Kentucky Legislature has rescinded the invitation to commissioners of other States to meet Kentucky commissioners at Louisville.

div4.head: The National Conscription — a New pledge of success.
div4.p:
Under this caption the New York Times says, equally, of the United States conscription bill, that sit too pledge that the Government will prevail as it means to gave itself.
Is enough muster into a service for three years all the able bodied men of the U. S. between 29 and 45, excepting Governors of States, Judges, the only sons of poor widows, and a very few others, giving a military force of three millions, enrolled by officials appointed by and directly accountable to the President, called forth by draft in such numbers and assigned to such places and duties as he pleases.
A Provost Marthal in every Congressional district will have entire responsibility for the completeness of his work.
Heavy Penalties for resistance, Every part of the bill bristles with provisions ensuring its efficiency.
The Government is now strong in power and strong enough in will.
The Confederate Congress has given its Executive a power which is practically unlimited; has indulged in no sticking about State Rights.
The Confederacy has put every dollar and every drop of blood at the command of Jeff Davis and if we do not make a similar submission we might as well make up our minds for infamous and ruinous discomfiture.
But the National Currency and Loan bills will pledge every dollar, and the National Conscription bill will pledge every drop of blood to the National cause.
This Conscription act will certainly pulverize the Confederacy, and, if necessary, repel the armed intervention of Napoleon III."

div4.head: The Position of the French Minister.
div4.p: The New York Times says:

q.p:
"It is no secret either at Washington or in this (New York) city that, from the first outbreak of this rebellion, M. Mercier has been in full sympathy with the Secessionists and in close communion with those who espouse their cause and give them all the aid and comfort in their power.
To all latents and purposes he has been actively engaged in intriguing with the Democratic sympathises with secession in the North from the beginning of the war," &c.

div4.head: News from Washington.
div4.p: The following Washington dispatches, dated the 19th inst., are published in the New York Times:
The friends of the Bank bill are confident it will pass the House.
At least twenty five millions have been stolen in the Quartermaster's Department during the past few months.

Gen. Scott's letter of Oct. 4, 1863, has been called for by the Senate.
It shows that McClellan treated Scott with disrespect while the latter was Commander in-Chief, and that Scott had determined to resign as soon as Halleck arrived from California.

During the discussion of the bill indemnifying the President as to political arrests, Mr. Voorhess distinguished himself by the boldness of his "treason," and was rebuked, by Mr. Dally, who said Northern rebels should be treated sternly by the Government, which evoked applause in the galleries, which Valiandigram irascibly demanded should be cleared.
Letters from the army of the Potemao express the utmost satisfaction with its condition and spirit, and show entire confidence in its success when the time comes for it to move.
Gen. Burnside left this evening for New York and will at once enter upon his new command.

Ninety-six thousand five hundred and sixty two bales of Government cotton have been sold in New York since the blockade of Southern ports, averaging $103 per bale, and ranging from 29 cents to $1 20½ per pound.
Height passenger trains new run daily from Washington to Baltimore, four of which are for New York.
The new gunboat Indianola ran the blockade at Vicksburg on the 14th, amid the rear of rebel artillery and the iron rain, and reached the mouth of the canal."

Newspapers have not been prohibited in the Army of the Potomac.
Hocker limited the newsboys to one for each division, and the boys refuse to sell until the order is rescinded.
The Philadelphia inquirer is reported to be prohibited from further sure in the army, and its correspondent arrested for publishing contraband news.
An effort is now being made to demoralize the troops by scattering broadcast among them treasonable sheets, and individual cases of desertion are not unfrequent.
Much of the army correspondence has naturally come under the head of "Irregular Proceedings," and a change is to be made in the status of the war chronicler.
The rebel line of earthworks now extend for fell ten miles down the river from Fredericksburg.

Gen. Butler had a grand reception in Baltimore on the 19th.
A most enthusiastic assembly was present, and 34 young ladies, crossed in white and bearing flags, sung patriotic airs.
He reviewed the past year, and said that another such year of progress would see the Confederacy annihilated.--Foreign interference could not save it, &c.

A Union gunboat was accidentally destroyed by fire at Caito on the 7th.
Loss $10,000.

Owing to the discussion of French mediation, the price of gold touched 164, finally leaving off at 15, Transactions very heavy.
Exchange 180.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
Sickness among the Yankee army at Vicksburg is increasing.
On the 14th a barge with 7,000 tons of coal ran the blockade successfully.
The town of Bolivar Landing, 50 miles above Memphis, has been destroyed by the gunboat Govington, in retaliation for the Jenny Lind's being fired into by guerillas.

Galveston is blockaded by the Brooklyn and Saloto.
The former is reported to be aground in 11 feet water.
Rebel fortifications are reported very strong.

In New Orleans it is reported that another vessel had slipped out of Mobile; that Federals had been repulsed at Port Hudson; that Sherman was fitting out another expedition, and the expedition to Bayon Teche had not started.
The white troops are making a fuse about being put on a level with negroes.
[Why don't the negroes resent being put on a level with Yankees?]
Near Island, No. 10 contraband goods in large quantities have been seized on four steamers, including a large and important rebel mail, and medicines, arms, blankets, and Confederate uniforms.
Fifteen blockade-running vessels have cleared from Nastau, and six have arrived safely from Southern ports.
The Constitutional, a Keokak newspaper, has been destroyed by convalescent soldiers.
Hooker has been made a Brigadier-General in the regular army.
Charles Carroll Kicks, a Richmond detective, was arrested in New York on the 20th.

John Van Buren, Senator Wilson said, on the 20th, in discussing illegal arrests, is a capital exponent of popular feeling and shows by his late speeches that the people are not sympathizers with traitors anywhere.
Once he said "let the erring sisters depart in peace;" now, he never will consent to recognize this traitor Confederacy; and for this Mr. Kahony undertakes to rebuke him, and thus proves that his own heart is "black with treason. "

The Charleston and Savannah channels, says the National Intelligencer, are full of torpedoes and obstructions, which, if they do not destroy the vessels, will detain them long enough under fire to be crippled seriously, and, judging from Fort McAllister, an easy victory need not be expected — That fort, it says, is as invulnerable as the Montauk, and until it is destroyed the torpedoes and obstructions above cannot be removed, and that iron-clads cannot pass.
The defences of Charleston equal those of Savannah.
There can then be no overwhelming attack, but more likely a protracted siege, which, if successful, will be a dear bought victory.
The Territory of Arizona has been "organized" by a bill passed in the United States Senate. Mr. Wade said he did not want the rebels to get a foothold even there.
The Illinois peace resolutions passed the House of Representatives of that State, but were lost in the Senate by the Republicans, who have a small majority absenting themselves.

The Queen of the West has made eight captures in all the steamers captured containing large quantities of pork, hogs, salt, molasses, sugar, and flour, intended for Port Hudson.
[The Yankees do not yet know it was " intended" that Port Hudson should "capture" the Queen of the West.]

The New York Times, of the 19th, has "with reluctance" become convinced that Louis Napoleon has determined to open Southern ports by the 1st of April for the expert of cotton, and that he will welcome rather than deprecate war as the consequence of his action.
It says the tenor of the ministerial journal — the Moniteur--and the liberal press, all unite to show that he has resolved to carry out this policy.
The Nanonal Intelligencer does not agree with the New York Times.
Joseph Holt is Judge-Advocate General, with the rank of Colonel.

The gunboat New Eva seized at or near Island No.10 the steamers Rowena, Knapp, and White Cloud, containing quinine, morphine, arms, army blankets, Confederate uniforms, and large quantities of other contraband goods.
The last named had a large rebel mail containing valuable information.

A dispatch from Fortress Monroe, dated the 19th, says "arrangements for the exchange of civilians have been perfected.
It is believed the Confederate Congress will overrule Jeff Davis's retaliatory proclamation, and the Virginia Legislature will authorize the transfer of officers imprisoned by Gov. Letcher to the Confederate authorities."
The New Orleans Delta, which was suppressed by Gen. Banks, was continued again on the representation of the workmen that their subsistence depended on it.
Portions of Gen. Welizel's forces had been sent to Port Vudson, owing to the result of some movements at that place.

The news from Galveston is, that the fleet entered the bay, but finding it strongly fortified, deemed it best to withdraw for the present.
A report from Galveston was current that the Brooklyn was aground in eleven feet water.

The "pirate" Florida called from Nassau on the 27th January.
Fourteen steamers, sloops, and schooners had arrived with cargoes of cotton and turpentine from Charleston, Savannah, and other ports, and some had sailed on their return trip.

The U. S. House of Representatives have concurred in the bill a ready passed by the Senate, to provide suctional currency secured by a pledge of United States stocks.
The bill awaits the signature of the President.

The correspondence of the Cincinnati Commercial says that Murfreesboro' is almost impregnable, and when the fortifications are complete, a small force can hold that portion of Middle Tennessee.
Nearly 400 refugees from conscription in East Tennessee and North Alabama have passed through there for Nashville.
Two division of Bragg's army were at Shelbyville.
Heavy skirmishes were of daily occurrence between the rebel cavalry and artillery and Yankee train guards.
Com Max. Woodhull, U. S. Navy, was killed at Fort Marshal, near Baltimore, by the accidental discharge of a gun while a salute was being fired in honor of Gen. Butler.

The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Times says it is a notorious fact that certain privates of the 93d New York regiment have kidnapped negroes and sold them to Secessionists outside of the Federal lines.
General Foster returned to the South on the 19th.
Gold closed at 162 per cent in New York on the 19th.

--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M., Mr. Hunter, of Va., in the chair.
Prayer by Rev. T. V. Moore, of the Presbyterian Church.
Mr. Baker, of Fla., offered a resolution proposing an amendment in the not, which was referred to the Judictary Committee.
Mr. Sparrow, of Louisiana, presented a petition of W. W. Palmer, of La., in relation to the prepayment of postage on newspapers.

Mr. Burnett, of Kentucky, from the Military Committee, reported back a House bill for the relief of certain officers and soldiers from the State of Missouri.
Placed on the calender.

Mr. Semmes, of La., from the Committee on the Judiciary, reported a bill relative to the bonds of quartermasters.
The bill was placed on the calendar.

The bill repealing acts heretofore passed allowing substitutes, with the amendment thereto, proposed by the Committee on Military Affairs, came up as unfinished business.
The amendment provides that on the desertion of a substitute the principal shall be placed in the army.
Messrs. Sparrow and Nurnett advocated and Mr. Orr opposed it. The amendment was rejected — ayes 9, noes 14.
The bill was then discussed, and on a vote to engross and read it a third time the ayes and noes were demanded.
It was determined in the affirmative.
The bill being put on its passage was carried.

The bill provides "that hereafter no person shall be received as a substitute for any person liable to perform military duty under the laws of the Confederate States, and all acts, or parts of acts, authorizing the acceptance of substitutes, are hereby repealed."
The Senate went into secret session, and on the opening of the doors adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by the Speaker.

Joint Resolutions.--Mr. Swann, of Tenn., offered a joint resolution of thanks to Gen. Braxton Bragg, and the officers and soldiers under his command, for gallant conduct in the battles before Murfreesboro', Tenn. Referred to Committee on Military Affairs.

Mr. Chilton, of Ala., offered a joint resolution expressing the sense of Congress as to the necessity for raising provisions, and the impolicy of planting for large crops of cotton and tobacco during the year 1863.
Referred to Committee on Foreign Affairs.

Mr. Garland, of Ark, offered a joint resolution authorizing the Postmaster-General to use certain revenues of the Post-Office Department in payment of its Liabilities.
Referred to Post- Office Committee.
Mr. Royston, of Ark., offered a joint preamble and resolutions respecting the payment of the usual currency of the Confederate States to the officers, agents and employers thereof.

Resolutions Referred,--By Mr. Chilton, of Ala.: A resolution that the Committee on the Judiciary be instructed to take into consideration, and at its earliest convenience report to this House, a bill providing for taking the census of the Confederate States, as required by the 2d clause of the 2d section of the 1st article of the Constitution.

By Mr. Royston, of Ark: A resolution that the Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments be instructed to inquire what further legislation is necessary in order to secure the payment of claims existing against the Government for subsistence and supplies furnished for the use of the army, and for which informal certificates or vouchers have been executed; and that they report by bill or otherwise.
By Mr. Halls, of Ala.: A resolution that the regular hour for meeting, for the remainder of the session, shall be a 11 o'clock A. M. Laid on the table.

Mr. Hilton, of Fla., submitted joint resolutions, adopted by the Legislature of that State relative to persons holding office in the State of Florida under the Confederate Government, subject to the Conscript act. Laid on the table.

By Mr. Hoage of Ky: A resolution that the Adjutant General be requested to call upon Maj. Gen Breckinridge for his official report of the operations of his command at the battles of Shilob, Baton Rouge, and Murfreesboro', and that when received copies thereof shall be sent to this House and shall be printed.
Referred to Committee on Military Affairs.
By Mr. Bruce, of Ky: A resolution to rescind the rule limiting speeches to thirty minutes. Laid on the table.

Several other resolutions were offered, among them one by Mr. Bruce, of Ky, in which was submitted an article from the Chicago Times, with reference to the freezing to death of Confederate prisoners at Camp Douglas.
The resolution contemplates inquiry into the matter, and proposing retaliation.
The resolution was agreed to.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, of La, the House went into secret session on the currency bill reported from the Committee of Ways and Means.

--The Senate met at 12 M., Mr. Johnson in the Chair.
Prayer by Rev. Mr. Moore, of the Presbyterian Church.

A communication from the House of Delegates communicated a series of resolutions in relation to the production of cereals in lieu of luxuries, such as tobacco, for the use of the army and the people, and invoking the co-operation of the farmers and planters of the Commonwealth, passed by the House, and sent to the Senate for concurrence.--Laid on the table.

A communication from the Executive transmitted some explanations touching certain statements contained in the report of the Committee on Confederate Relations in regard to the State Line, wherein it was charged that companies were formed with less numbers than were required by law.
The Executive communication was laid on the table, ordered to be printed, and referred to the Committee on Confederate Relations.

Mr. Douglas offered a preamble and accompanying resolutions in relation to Col. Henry Hill, of the Paymaster's Department of the Virginia forces, left without an appointment by the abolishment of the State Line, reiterating the confidence of the General Assembly in his personal and official integrity, and recommending, until otherwise provided for by the Confederate Government, that the Governor be requested to make him an allowance out of the military contingent fund at least equal to the pay and emoluments of his rank as an old army officer.
Laid over under the rules.
The bill to supply vacancies in the General Assembly in counties, cities, and districts within the power of the public enemy, occupied the reason in discussion of its merits pro and con

Mr. Robertson moved to refer the whole matter to the Committee on Courts of Justice, with instructions to inquire into the expediency of a convention to determine the matter of representation, which was rejected, and the bill was ordered to its engrossment and third reading.

Mr. Marshall calling up his resolutions in relation to the stocking by the Confederate States of the Virginia Railroads with engines sufficient to convey the demands of the State and Confederate authorities, and recommending the stocking of the same by the Confederate Government, the whole matter was referred to the special Committee on Salt.
On motion, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met at 11 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Duncan, of the M. E. Church.
Senate bill incorporating the Farmville Insurance Company was read a second time and ordered to its engrossment.
Senate resolution suspending the salary of Judge J. E. Pitts was read and, on motion of Mr. Prince, referred to the Committee on Courts.
The bill providing for the sale of place of land near the Penitentiary was read a second time and ordered to its engrossment.
On motion of Mr. Richardson, the bill incorporating a company for the improvement of the north fork of the Holston river, in the county of Smythe, was read a third time and passed.
Mr. Orgain submitted a resolution, which was agreed to, inquiring into the expediency of incorporating a company for the manufacture of coal oil in the county of Kanawha.

On motion of Mr. Bouldin, the bill amending certain sections of an act passed October 31, 1862, entitled "an act to provide for the public defence," authorizing the Governor to call out a certain proportion of the male slaves of the State to work upon fortifications and other public works, when requested so to do by the President of the Confederate States, was taken up, read a second time, and, during its consideration.

Mr. Hepkins moved that the rules heretofore issued by the House against Mr. George Whitfield be dismissed, that gentleman having appeared before the committee and fully answered all interrogatories propounded.
The motion was agreed to.

The hour for the consideration of the tax bill having arrived, the House refused to take up the same, and proceeded to further discuss the bid under consideration at the time of Mr. Hopkins motion, which was continued up to the hour of adjournment.

argument.p: running the blockade — another steamer Ashore--the French steamer Ronandin.

div4.p: --A British steamer reached a Confederate port yesterday.

Another British steamer, in entering this port last night, ran aground on the shoals about one mile from Sullivan's Island.
The bench where she now lies is in full view of the blockaders.
She contains a very valuable cargo from Nassau.
The news at Nassau was unimportant.
The iron clads Chicora and Palmatto State have gone down to protect her, and it is expected she will be afloat this afternoon.
The French war steamer Ronardin was tugged off the shoals this morning, and is now within the harbor.
It is rumored that another merchantman steamer from Nassau got aground last night several miles above Sullivan's Island, but the report needs confirmation.

div3.head: From the West--Fremont and Butler — more prizes captured.
div3.p:
--Parties from the front report that cannonading was heard in the direction of Unionville, on our left, yesterday morning.
It is reported that Rosecrans has advanced half-way between Murfreesboro' and Middleson.
Dispatches to the Nashville Union of the 18th, state that Fremont has been sent to Texas, and that Butler returns to New Orleans.
Three prizes were captured by the Alabama off Kinston.

div3.head: City Council.
div3.p:
--A called meeting of this body was held at the Council room.
City Hall, at 4 o'clock yesterday evening.
Present: Messrs. Saunders, Wyane, Hill, Burr, Scott, Hasting Grattan, Glansbrook, Denoon, Grifflu, Crutchfield Stokes and Ipps.

The President stated the object of the meeting to be the consideration of "an ordinance imposing taxes for the support of the city government."--It was discussed five hours, variously amended, and adopted with the above title.
[The demand upon our space prevents a longer notice this morning.]
Mr. Burr offered the following resolution, which was adopted.:
Resolved, That the Committee on the Gas Works inquire and report to the Council upon the propriety of charging and collecting from the city the cost of lighting the streets with gas.
On motion of Mr. Crutchfield at 9 o'clock, the Council adjourned.

div3.head: Pardoned.
div3.p:
--The Governor yesterday extended Executive clemency to Frances Marion, a female, sent to the Penitentiary by the Circuit Court of Albemarle for one year for receiving stolen goods.
Her son and husband were both in the army, and she was the mother of ten children, James Lively, who was sent for two years by the Circuit Court of Marshall county, for obtaining goods by false pretences, was also pardoned by the Governor on yesterday.
In this case great doubt existed whether the defendant had ever committed the crime alleged against him.

div3.head: Sent to the Penitentiary.
div3.p: --Edward Sullivan, one of a half dozen youths who, a few months since, at night, fell on Neal Ivey, a countryman, near the Varieties Theatre and, after knocking him down robbed him of $85 in money, was tried before a jury in the Hustings Court on Monday and sent to the Penitentiary for three years.

div3.head: Decided.
div3.p: --A decision was rendered yesterday, in the Supreme Court of Appeals, in the case of Mathew A. Cox vs. Burwell Sheppard, on an appeal from a decree rendered by the Circuit Court of Buckingham county, in April, 1859, confirming the original decree.

div3.head: Recovery of Government harness.
div3.p: --Officers Custis and Barke, of the Provost Marshal's office, recovered yesterday, from a house on Broad street, a quantity of Government harness valued at several hundred dollars, which was carried to the Marshal's office.

div3.head: Called for.
div3.p:
--A few weeks since a call was made by the Government on the citizens of Richmond for five hundred and thirty able bodied male negroes.
The Aldermen's Hustings Court was summoned to assess the number that should be furnished by such slaveholders as should come under the operation of the law, but they never met, and the Governor, after being notified of the fact, did not order a new session of the Court for the purpose of making the necessary assessment.
The work is yet to be done.
The levy on Henrico county for 350 slaves promptly responded to by the county justices, and the negroes are to be delivered to the Government agents to-day at the Court-House.

div3.head: The city gas.
div3.p:
--The very poor quality of the city gas has been remarked for some time past, and, in order that no blame should attach to those having charge of the works, it is proper that the reason therefore should be stated.
The coal used in generating the light has generally proved, on trial, to be half state and hard coal, with very little gas in it. The colliers have no place to stow coal, and the consequence is that furnished the city has been very wet. More coal is carbonized now at the works than ever before, and yet less gas and coke is produced than at any time heretofore.
Hardly enough coke can be obtained to keep the furnaces going.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p:
--Mrs. Mary Vanderlip, proprietress of an oyster saloon, on Broad street, was summoned up to day to show cause why she should not be fined for keeping a disorderly house, and sailing whiskey and other liquors without obtaining a license so to do. The proof in the case was supplied with so much readiness that the Mayor found no difficulty in determining that in regard to the charge of selling liquor the law had been violated seven times.--Fines to the amount of $140 were imposed, being twenty dollars in each case.
On the charge of keeping a disorderly house the proof was equally conclusive, and for this Mrs. Vanderlip was required to furnish security to appear before the Grand Jury and answer an indictment.
Overton Balley slave of Dr. Randolph Harrison arrested for not having a pass and having in his possession an overcoat supposed to be stolen, was examined and acquitted.

William Logan, arrested for drawing a bowis, knife on William B Lyons, in his own house, and injuring said Lyons's furniture, was required to give security for his good behavior, and, falling to do so, was committed to jail.

Hustings Court, Tuesday, Feb. 21th --Judge Wm. H. Lyons presiding.--Kitas Vanderlip, a person confined in the city jail on conviction for misdemeanor, was brought up from the prison and put upon trial for being engaged in garroting Izaac Jacobs, a person temporarily confined in the jail, who was set upon by several prisoners (amongst whom it was said was Vanderlip) and robbed of a watch and five hundred and fifty dollars in money.
The jury, after hearing the evidence of Jacobs and others, retired, and, after some time spent in consultation, returned with a verdict of not guilty.--Vanderlip was carried back to serve cut his time as a prisoner for misdemeanor.

Patrick O'Donnell and Patrick O'Neal were put on trial for robbing Jno. W. Burnett of a shawl on the highway, after putting said Burnett in great bodily fear.
They were found guilty, and their term of imprisonment assessed at three years in the penitentiary.
The prisoners garroted the witness before relieving him of his shawl.

On Monday, in this Court, Adam Shaler was convicted of stealing $1,000 from a fellow-boarder at the house of Mrs. Graves, corner of Mayo and Franklin streets, and sent to the State prison for one year.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrice county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at auction.
div3.p:
--At Administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1862, commending at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses; together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co, and as such Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J M Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J A Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of valuable Real and personal property at auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at public auction, Tuesday, the 10th of March next, on the premises, the Farm of Povall Turner, dec'd, (known at Pitts's,) on the Chickahominy river, in the county of New Kent. three miles from Summit Depot, on the York River Railroad and twenty miles from Richmond, containing 62d acres, of which about 400 are in a high state of cultivation, well enclosed, and adapted to the growth of corn, wheat and oats, with 195 bushels of winter oats, and 24 bushels of wheat seeded and a portion merled and set in clover, with a dwelling house and all other necessary out houses, and a well of excellent water in the yard.
The balance of the land is in original growth of pine, oah, maple, and cypress.
Also the Farming Utensile, stock of valuable Mules Horse, Oxen, Cows, Sheep, and Hose, Also, Bugles, Carriages, Carts, Wagon, Core, Oats, Fodder, Hay, Shucks, and Straw; Household and Kitchen Furniture Bacon Lard, and Poultry.

Also, at the same time and place a Tract of Land, detached from and within a quarter of a mile of the farm, containing 80 acres, well enclosed with a plank fence, one-half in cultivation, with valuable low grounds, and well for a pasturage.
Also, 50 acres lying on the York River Railroad fifteen miles from Richmond, which has on it a dwelling-house, and some wood and timber wanting on it.
Also, a first-class Steam Saw Mill and fixtures of twenty-four horse power, in good repair.
Terms--For the real estate, made known on the day of sale; each will be required for the perishable property.

Commissioner's Sale of the valuable Real Estate known as the "Richmond," at the corner of Governor and Ross streets.
As Executor of the late Dr. John Cullen, and as Commissioners of the Court of the city of Richmond, appointed by a decree entered on the 15th January, 1863, in the case of "Cullen's ex' or against Cullen and als," I shall proceed to sail at public auction, on the on Monday, the 9th March, 1863, at 12 o'clock M. the valuable real estate seized, known as the Richmond House.
This property has a front on Ross street of 62½ feet, and a depth on the East line of Ross street of 124 feet to an alley.
The building is a large brick one, having a large number of rooms, besides several offices on Governor street, and in admirably well adapted for the purposes of a boarding-house.
Its location and other advantages are amongst the best in the city.

Terms.--One fifty cash; balance at 6, 12, 18 and 24 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained till all the purchase money in fully paid.
The taxes and insurance for this year to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
Gustavus A Myers,
Ex'or of Dr. John Cullen, dec'd
And Com'r of the Court.
P. S.--By a supplemental decree, entered a few days ago, the purchaser of the foregoing real at his election, pay all the purchase money in cash.
G. & A. Aucts. [fe 23]

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 48, page 2.

div3.head: Resistances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscription, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be sent should be in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch Richmond, Virginia," and stated with war, writing the subscriber's Game, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to day agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Sent a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and follow them.

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of NONPAREILor Agate Type.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: Government credit.
div3.p:
The best and only permanent means of maintaining the credit of a Government is taxation. --The expedients of our own Government — such as printing on the face of the paper issues that they were "findable in eight per cent. bonds of the Confederate States"--have been unavailing in the face of the continued emission of that paper.
To the great body of the people the promise of eight per cent. added not a title of value to the note for this eight per cent, could only date from the time the note on whose face it is pledged is converted into the bond, and the marses will be unable to hold the bonds.
They will fall into the hands of speculators, extortioners, corrupt quartermasters, etc. But we can produce high authority to show that this eight per cent. pledge, made to keep up the credit of the note on which it is printed, is not considered binding.
Prominent statesmen have seriously proposed that all of those notes not offered for conversion by a certain day shall be denied the right of conversion into eight per cent. bonds, and another proposition goes so far as to say that all not brought in by a certain day for exchange for bonds shall cease to be currency.
One proposition is to repudiate the Government's pledge as to interest; the other is, we suppose, to repudiate the issues of the Government in all transactions with the Government — i. e., they will not be received in payment to the Government.
It is hardly possible that there can be any purpose to repudiate them altogether; but the effect upon the credit of the notes so put under she ban must be seriously injurious to the holders.

So that the promise of interest, like other expedients, cannot keep up the credit of a piece of paper which is itself but a promise.
The true basis of credit is a wise system of finance based on solid revenues, including a liberal tax paid by a people able and willing to pay it. We have no idea that our Government designs repudiating anything — not even interest that in promised on its notes.
But its only resort, sooner or later, to raise the means to pay its debts is taxation The sooner it shows its determination to employ this only reliable agent the better.
Congress may beat the bush and waste time diseassing futile schemes for "retiring" the currency, but until it goes boldly to work on a tax bill and passes it, there will be really nothing done to elevate the credit of the Government's paper — nay, nor anything whatever added to the means for the prosecution of the great undertakings now forced upon its shoulders.

div3.head: Boasted Northern superiority.
div3.p:
The arrogant assumption by the North of intellectual and military superiority to the South has been completely exploded in the judgment of all mankind by the present war. But there never was any ground for that self-complacent and impudent assumption.
The liberties of the United States were established by the greatness and valor of a Southern military leader, and its Constitution was the product of Southern wisdom and patriotism.
The very fact complained of by jealous Northern sectionalists, that the Federal Government was, for the greater part of its history, administered by Southern Presidents is of itself an answer to the ridiculous assumption of Northern intellectual superiority.
If the theory be true that the people are capable of selecting the wisest men of the nation as their rulers, how came they so uniformly to select them from the South, unless Southern statement possessed superior qualifications for Government!. And if success be the test of ability, what better proof can be required of the competency of the long line of Southern statement who held the helm of the ship of State, than the gigantic progress of the U. States, unparalleled in ancient and modern times, under their administrations!
It was not till Northern demagogues obtained power that the fortunes of the Federal Government began to wane.
Superiority in numbers and in wealth, the product of partial legislation, was the only superiority that the North could justly claim over the South.
The Father of his Country was a Southerner, its greatest jurist a Southerner, its greatest orator a Southerner, its most illustrious military leaders Southern.
This was true of the second war with England as well as the first.--Jackson was the most distinguished soldier of the war of 1812, and Taylor and Scott had no rivals in the war with Mexico, a war to which the South, with her inferior numbers, contributed the great mass of the rank and file, as well as the Generals.
These are not empty boasts, but well ascertained historical facts.
None but the most impudent and arrogant people on the earth could have had the brass to claim superiority over the South in the face of such a record.

The present war has given the final blow to their pompous pretensions.
With the most unlimited resources of men and means, they have mismanaged their financial and military capabilities in the most disgraceful and ruinous manner.
They have been baffled by Southern statesmen and Southern soldiers at every turn.
What could not the South have done with such resources as the North has possessed?
Northern superiority indeed!
If they know the meaning of shame, they would never venture to utter those words again.

div3.head:
Depot army Committee Y. M. C. A.
and ladies' soldiers' aid Society.
Richmond, Feb. 23d, 1863.
div3.p:
The citizens of Richmond are requested to sent to our Depot, corner of Bank and 10th streets, any articles of Clothing or Furniture which can be spared, however plain, for the use of soldiers' wives and children who have been placed under our charge.
Contributions for this object thankfully received.

Letters for the following persons are left at Messrs Purcell, Ladd & Co's: J. J. Allen, Elize J. Armistead, J. Bryan, Wm. H. Bullock, G. w. Barnes, J. W. Beasley, G. W. Berry, Elizabeth Bagley, J. Bonny, G. F. Clark, Trute R. Campbell, F. A. Cunningham, Samuel Davenport, J. H. Day. L. Frederich. Wm. Fleming, R. H. Fome, H. H. Foy, Cary J. Hall, Mosse Hudgine, Albert Jordan, E. R. Johnson, J. T. Jobson, Virginia T. Langhorne, C. S. Maurice, P. B. Malbone, R. A. MOreland; J. B. Massiau, E. C. Murray. C. M. O'Rell, M. Rosenberg, W. H. Rogers, Jno Rancy, A. A. Fimcoe, Campt J. D. Sims, J. Vickers, D. Wilson, J. R. Webb, R. R. Watton, B. H. Williams.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--The subscriber, a true Virginian, will Lecture from the Washington Monument, in this place, on Friday, the 27th inst., beginning at 11 o'clock A. M. Subject: "The Degeneracy of Man." The President of the Confederate States, the members of Congress, the Governor of Virginia, the members of the State Legislature, and citizens and soldiers of the Southern Confederacy generally, are specially invited to attend.
I shall begin when the city cloak strikes 11.

div3.head: Masonic notice.
div3.p:
--The members of Richmond Lodge, No. 10, are summoned to attend a meeting this morning, at 10 o'clock, to pay the last tribute of respect to our deceased brother, Ceo W. Apperson. Carriages will be in attendance for the use of the brothers.
Our sister Lodges and transient brethren are invited to attend.
div3.closer:
By order of the W. Master.
Jas E. Riddick, Sec'y. fe 25--1t*

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The annual meeting of the Directors of the Chickahominy and James River Steam Navigation Company will be held at the office of the Virginia life Insurance Company, at 5 o'clock P. M., on the of March next; and the annual meeting of the Stockholders at 5 o'clock P. M. on the 4th of March next, at the same place.
Those old stockholders who have not signed the bill of sale for the Shults are earnestly requested to attend.

The Second Lecture in the course before the Young Men's Christian Association will be delivered on Thursday Evening next, the 26th instant at 7" o'clock, in the First Prosbyterian Church (Dr. Mcore's,) by the Hon J. L. M. Curry, of Alsbame.
Subject--"Selthood"
Tickels canb be had at the Door, the Hotels, and at the Bookstores.

div3.head:
Office of the Roanoke Valley
R. E. Co.
Clarksville, Va.
div3.p: A meeting of the stockholders of this Company will be held in the town of Clarksville on Thursday, the 19th day of March 1863, and it is earnestly desired that a full attendance should be had.
div3.closer:
By order of the Board of Directors.
E. A. Williams, Sec'y. fe 14--2awt19thM.

div4.p: At the residence of the bride's father, on Sunday morning, 22d inst., by the Rev. Gilbert Mason. Mr. Luther M. Morrisett and Miss. Louisa M. Walker, all of Chesterfield county.
On the 12th instant, by the Rev. G. W. Woodbridge, Mr. Wm. Randolph to Miss. Fredericca Wright, both of this city. *
on Monday night, February 23d, at a quarter past 1 o'clock, after a short illness, Owen Rowland, in the 20th year of his age.

lg.l: go, lovely one; no longer mine.
to gaze on beauty all divine;
Though great the loss,
I thee resign.
Thy days on earth but few have been,
yet many afflictions Thou hast seen;
and freed at last from pain and sin,
Thou shall with saints be welcome in.
Your body in the grave will sleep,
While we for Owen lonely weep;
But we hope with thee are long to tell,
Our Saviour hast done all things well.

div4.p: His funeral will take place on Wednesday evening at 3½ o'clock, from St. Peter's Cathedral. *
on Tuesday, February 24th, after a short illness, Georgie, youngest son of George a and Teresa Freeburger, aged 13 months.

lg.l: Lay him gently in the coffin,
Fold his arms across his breast,
Wrap the cold shroud around him,
our little George has gone to rest!
Oh, my heart is sad and lonely,
As I weep above thy bed;
And my home is lone and dreary.
For my darling George is dead!

div4.p: The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully requested to attend the funeral from the residence of his father on Cherry street, between Main and Cary, on Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clk.
At his residence in this city, on Monday, the 23d inst, George W. Apperson, in his 61st year.
His friends are invited to attend his funeral from the Masons' Hall this morning, at 12 o'clock. *

in Charles city co, on the 16th inst., of typhoid fever, Martha C, wife of James T. Barlow, and daughter of C. C. Folkes, in the 28th year of her age, leaving three children and a devoted husband to mourn their loss.

lg.l: Farewell, dear Martha,
Thy Saviour has called thee
We doubt not to rest.
We hope soon to meet thee
In that blest abode,
Where the smiles of the Saviour
Will be the feast of the soul. *

div4.p:
Killed at the battle of Sharpsburg, and left on the field Samuel A. Meredith, in the 24th year of his age, youngest son of H. H. Meredith, Sr. of Lynchburg, and a member of the Lynchburg Beauregard Artillery.
Lt. C. R. Phelps Comd'g. *
Died, at his residence, in Lynchburg, Friday morning, 20th February, 1863, Henry Hickman Meredith, Sr. in the 91st year of his age.

Mr. Meredith was born in King and Queen county, Va. in 1772, and went to Lynchburg at the age of 15 years, where he has remained ever since, and at the time of his death was the oldest inhabitant of that place. *
On the 17th of February at the Marine Hospital, B. F. Lamedin, of St. Michaels Yalbot co, Md.,
Baltimore and Easton (Md.) papers please copy. *

div3.head: Deserted.
div3.p: --From Dabney's Heavy Field Artillery--Wm. A. Norton, 19 years of age; 5 feet 8 ¾ inches high; dark hair; dark blue eyes, scar on right lip; a sore on left ankle; born in Fredericksburg.
Geo. H. Montford, 21 years of age; 5 feet 7¼ inches high; light hair; gray eyes; born in Elaton, Maryland.
They both left the company at Halifax on the 16th inst., The usual reward of $30 will be paid for their arrest.
div3.closer:
Capt. Wm. J. Dabney,
Weldon, Hall. fe 25--3t*

div3.head:
Ordnance Dep't of Va.,
Richmond, Feb'y. 20, 1863.
div3.p: Second Class Militia.--Officers of the Second Class Militia to whom arms have been issued for their companies by this Department are hereby required to deliver the same to me, at the Virginia Armory, corner of 7th and Cary sts, with as little delay as possible.
div3.closer:
By order:
P. G. Coghlan, Captain.
Ordnance Dep't of Va. fe 21--ts

div3.head: Substitute.
div3.p:
--A young man, Southern born, healthy and strong, and well recommended and free from conscription, can be secured as a Substitute for cavalry or artillery service, if immediate application is made, and a liberal price offered.
Address "D. D. B." through the Post Office, stating where an interview can be had.

div3.head: Substitute notice.
div3.p:
--A young man, with satisfactory testimonials, and exempt from conscription will go as a Substitute in a good light artillery company, or battery of heavy artillery, for a fair consideration.
Address "X. Y. X." through the Post-Office.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--One over 45 years of age, must come well recommended.
Apply at room No. 31, American Hotel, between the hours of 9 and 10 A. M. and 2 and 3 P. M.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go into an infantry company now near Fredericksburg.--A man over 45 years of age and a Virginia, preferred.
Call at No. 99, Ballard House, this day, from 9 to 2 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid for a Substitute over forty five. One with references required.
Call at R. H. Dieebell's, between 9 and 10 o'clock.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A Girl, 16 years of age, who is an excellent House Servant and Nurse; also, a Woman, with two children whom I would put out to a good home for their food and Clothes.
Inquire of
div3.closer:
T Tayloe Engineers' Headq'rs,
Cor. 28th and Grace sts. fe 25--2t*

div3.head: For Sale.
div3.p: --A good Cook and Laundress, with a likely mulatto female child six years old.

Also, for hire, from the 1st of March, a first-rate Cook and Laundress, with three children.
Apply to Mrs. Judge Clopton, on Franklin st., between 3d and 4th.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--For the balance of the year, two negro Women, who can cook, wash, and iron.
Apply at Thos Jones's, No. 8 Main st.

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A Woman suitable for a wet nurse.
She is a good seamstress, washer and ironer.
Apply at Mrs. Pandleton's on Cary street, between 3d and 4th.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --The Magistrates of Henrico county having impressed my only negro man to work on fortifications, I will pay a liberal price for an able bodied Hand to work in his place for 60 days. He is at work on batteries near Richmond.
div3.closer:
A. J. Torrell, M. D.
On Brooke Road, 4½ miles from Richmond. fe 25--2t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a gentleman of some experience, and exempt from military service, a situation as Salesman or General Assistant in some commercial house, (auction or commission preferred.) Reliable city references given.
Address "L. H." Dispatch office,

div3.head: Wanted.--a Boy.
div3.p:
--Wanted immediately, an honest Lad, who writes a good plain hand, understand figures well, and is willing to make himself useful to his employer.
Apply at Taylor's Music Store, North side of Main, between 9th and 10th sts. Richmond.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To buy a handsome set of Rosewood or Mahogany Chamber Furniture.
A good price will be paid for the same if application is made immediately.
No one need call unless it is handsome and modern.
Call at 92 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young man to aid in recruiting a company in a desirable branch of the service, for a Lieutenancy.
Address "Captain," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good situation as Manager on a Farm by a man of small family and exempt from military duty.
Address "A. B. C," Dispatch office, any time within three days.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --Board in a private family, on Shockoe Hill, for a gentleman and wife.--Apply at 161 Main st. Best of references will be given.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--One or two Rooms, furnished or unfurnished, between 9th and 15th streets for which a liberal rent will be paid.
Address "G. E," Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Druggist.
One well acquainted with compounding prescriptions may apply corner of Broad and 25th streets, Richmond, Va.,

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A good Cook, Washer and Ironer, at No. 36 Main street, two doors below the St. Charles Hospital.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A man to work on the Batteries.
I will pay $150 for sixty days, in addition to the Government pay. Apply at the Dispatch office this day.

div3.head: Wanted — Flax Seed.
div3.p: --I will pay the highest cash price for Flax Seed in any quantity.
div3.closer:
W. L. Montague
Corner Bank and 12th sts. fe 14--4t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good middle-aged colored Nurse.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Matron in a hospital, or Housekeeper in a private family.
Address "M. M," Winder Hospital.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A lady qualified to teach Music wishes to engage a number of Scholars.
Terms moderate.
Apply at the store of Smith & Harwood.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A Situation to superintend a Machine Ship or Foundry by a competent Machinist and Draughtsman.
Address "H," box 696. Richmond.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for the apprehension and securing, so that I get them, of two negroes.
Taylor and Boss, who left my premises about the 1st of May, 1863, or $50 for either of them.
Taylor is about 15 years old dark skin, very quick and sprightly, and I understand was with Capt. Mitchell, of the 11th Ga. reg't, last June, and now supposed to be somewhere in Gen. Longstreet's corps, if not with that regiment, and passes by the name of "Free Bill" Boss is 22 years old, a tall, likely mulatto, a scar on the check caused by a burn; believed to be harbored in this city.
Information left with W. S. Phillips, 12th street, of Dr. F. W. Hancook, Main street, between 3d and 4th.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $100 for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my man George if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on the 14th inst., about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about 6 feet high, 21 years old, brown color, and weights about 190 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp or try to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black hat.

Commissioner's Sale of Lot and Dwelling-House in the city of Richmond.--As Commissioners acting under a decree of the Carsuit Court of the city of Richmond, pronounced on the 7th day of February, 1863, in the case of French Guardian, Mr. Smith and others, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 2d day of March, 1863, beginning at 4 o'clock P. M. the property in said decree contained, consisting of a lot of ground, with a wooden dwelling-house and other improvements thereon, fronting 30 feet on the East line of 2d street, between Lee and running back 130 feet.

Ters--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until all the purchase money be paid and a conveyance directed by the Court; or the purchaser at his option, may pay the whole purchase money in cash.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
R. E. Hewison, Comm'r.
Sale conducted by Williamson &Co., Aucts. fe 17

div3.p:
Commissioner Sale of A half Acrts Lot, No. 22, in Duval's Addition, at the corner of St.
Stephen and Sharity sts.--As Commissioner of the Court of Richmond, appointed by a decree entered on the 12th of February, 1863, in the case of Coleman against Relt, &c. I shall proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, 25th Feby. 1863,at 4 o'clock P. M., the above valuable Lot fronting 144 feet on the west side of St.
Stehens street, running back on the south side of Charity street 122 feet, and adjoining the residence of Capt Appe.

Terms.--One third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, and title retained until the further order of the Court.
The taxes for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
R. H. Colleman, Com'r.
Sale by Goddin & Apperson. Auct's. fe 14

div3.head: Beautiful improved Farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or Fifteen negroes, for Sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albamarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premieres, on Tuesday, the 2d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day,) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Creek, containing about 650 This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abundance of timbers, is smooth and gently undulating, of a high degree of improvements has a large passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well set in old grass yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling house, and all the necessary out-houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.
